AIR POLLUTION IN JURONG



    The following Question stood in the name of Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon -

    4. To ask the Minister for the Environment what is the level of air pollution in the Jurong area and whether the air is safe for human beings.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tiong Bahru GRC): Question No.4,Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the levels of various air pollutants such as total acidity, smoke, suspended particles, sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides in various parts of Singapore, including Jurong, have been kept under continuous monitoring since 1971. The results show that the level of air pollution in Jurong, as well as in other parts of Singapore, is well within the ambient air quality standards recommended by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA).

    The levels of various pollutants in Jurong are not only within the standards but are also very low. For example, the 1988 levels of sulphur dioxide, total acidity and nitrogen dioxide in Jurong were 35, 24 and 35 ug/Nm3 respectively. The WHO standards for these pollutants are 80, 60 and 100 ug/Nm3 respectively.

    As a large part of Jurong is industrial, the air in Jurong, admittedly, would not be as good as that in other parts of Singapore which are largely rural or residential.

    Nonetheless, Sir, the air in Jurong is safe.

Column: 211



     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC): Sir, what are the main sources of pollution in Jurong? Secondly, what steps have been taken to minimize the pollution from these sources?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the more pollutive industries in Jurong are those with large fuel-burning equipment and these are mainly the petro-chemical plants,the oil refineries and the power stations. Besides complying with the emission standards specified in the Clean Air Act, these industries, as an added precaution, are sited at remote locations or on offshore islands so that the impact on population centres is further minimized.

    Sir, other sources of pollution in Jurong, particularly the Jurong North Area, are the brickworks. It has nothing to do with Brickworks Constituency. In the past, when the area was scarcely populated, pollution from brickworks had little or no impact at all on the surrounding areas. With the development of highrise HDB flats in Jurong East, Jurong West and Bukit Batok, the soot from these brickworks are affecting the people; so they complain. What my Ministry had done was to require these brickworks to phase out the use of old kilns which were the main source of pollution because of the poor design. In fact, Sir, the brickworks which are allowed to remain in the Jurong North area are those with newer and cleaner kilns.

     The Chairman: Main and Development Estimates of Singapore for the financial year 1st April, 1989 to 31st March, 1990, contained in Paper Cmd. 8 of 1989.     Members on the Front Bench are also urged to keep their replies precise so as to allow as many Backbenchers as possible to speak on their amendments within the guillotine times.

    I would like to remind Members that under the Standing Orders, they must confine their observations to the subject under discussion and may not introduce irrelevant matters.

Column: 213



    A Member should also not engage in tedious repetition, either of his or her own arguments, or of the arguments used by other Members in the debate. If a point or points made by the Member had already been made by some other Member, I shall not hesitate to ask the Member to discontinue his or her speech.

    A Member who has not given notice of an amendment cannot speak on it until the Members whose names appear below the amendment have spoken and the Minister concerned has replied, provided that there is still time left for the amendment and the subject he wishes to speak on is relevant to the matters raised.

    A Member who has indicated that he wishes to speak on a matter affecting policy but speaks on a detail of expenditure will be ruled out of order.

    Strict observation of these rules are necessary to ensure the brisk conduct of the business before us.

    I remind Members that I shall be listening to them for the next 10 days. While I have been credited by others with the virtue of patience, I venture to tell Members not to attempt to test the limits of my endurance.

    That having been said, we can now begin.

    Head B

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head B be reduced by $10 in respect of Code BA 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, $0.35 million is to meet legal fees for the engagement of a QC or QCs for the expenses incurred as a result of legal action taken by or against the Government. The Privy Council recently heard the appeal of Mr J B Jeyaretnam and I assume that the Government must have also engaged a QC to look after its interest in the Privy Council hearing. If so, would the Minister inform the House what these claims and costs were and, if not, would the Minister inform the House what the budgetted expenses are for and has any funds been used for claims and costs in 1988?

Column: 214



    I wonder if I may also bring in a small item which is connected with the Attorney-General's Office or the Government. It is the news items that was published in the newspapers this morning, namely, the decision to ban QC Anthony Lester from working in Singapore. This man, according to the newspapers, has been conducting political activity outside the court. I wonder if that is the real reason why he has been barred from coming to Singapore. If that is the reason then no lawyer should be allowed to carry on political activity outside the court. But I see many lawyers are doing that. So what reason is there for not allowing a QC to come to work in Singapore?

     The Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Sir, on his first point as to the precise details of expenditure involved in the services of QC engaged by the Government, obviously Ministers do not carry these details in the head and if the Member were to file a Question on this specific point the information will be supplied to him.

    May I turn to his second point. He has not read the Government press statement correctly. Mr Lester has not been allowed any more professional visit passes to come to Singapore to work as a QC, not for the reasons that he stated, but because he has abused his privilege, ie, the privilege which we grant to British QCs of appearing in our courts. He has abused his privilege in that he has carried out a crusade and campaign for his client beyond the confines of the court. Dr Lee Siew-Choh argued that what the Government had done was to say that the lawyer cannot be a politician. This has never been the position of the Government. The sole reason why Mr Lester has been denied a professional visit pass is that he has abused the privilege. He has mounted a campaign on behalf of Teo Soh Lung and others abroad, agitated against the Singapore Government, has threatened and intimidated the Government and, by the account of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of England itself who told our High Commissioner, he is in the forefront of the legal circles mounting pressure on the British government. These are the reasons, Sir. It is highly improper for a lawyer who is

Column: 215

appearing in a case on behalf of a client to crusade and campaign for the client beyond the confines of the court. It has nothing to do with whether the lawyer in a separate capacity wants to be a politician, but he cannot abuse his role as a lawyer to mount a campaign for his client beyond the courts.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Mr Speaker, Sir, he has said that the QC threatened and intimidated the Singapore Government. I find it impossible to believe a thing like that happening. In fact, as far as I know, the Government intimidates other people instead.

    As regards the abuse of privilege, Sir, you must understand that a big principle is involved - the principle of upholding justice. In the circumstances, the upholding of justice may be allowed on anywhere in this world, not necessarily inside the court. And if the Government insists that the lawyers can only speak on the issue inside the court, then the principles involved will have to be completely swept aside.

    Sir, I think the courts of justice all over the world allow people to speak on issues like that, and I think the Government should not be harsh if somebody should speak up for lawyer Teo Soh Lung.

     Prof. Jayakumar: The Member is entitled to his view if he thinks it is proper for a lawyer who is representing a client in a court to also act as a propagandist and a campaigner and as a crusader beyond the confines of the court. That principle certainly is not the principle on which we have operated in Singapore. That is not the principle which the British allow in their system, and certainly it is not a principle which we are going to change now, just because the Member feels that it is expedient.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Would the Minister then say that this principle is exclusive for the Singapore Government? At the present moment, there are protests already from the British government and, I suppose, more protests would come from Europe and other places.

Column: 216



     Prof. Jayakumar: This is not a principle which is peculiar or unique to Singapore. This is a principle which is universally recognized in the Commonwealth - a lawyer should not confuse his role as a lawyer; he must keep to the confines of representing the best interests of his client, of adducing the best arguments to the court in favour of his client's case and to persuade the court to listen to, and decide on, the legal arguments - not to crusade and be a propagandist outside the court.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Whether things like that will be interpreted as crusading depends on the views of the people who are being crusaded against, if I may use the same word. But then, Sir, these are universal principles upheld by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. And in the circumstances, no one should be penalized if he should speak up on such principles.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will be enlightened if the Member can point out where in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights is provided that, first, a country must allow foreign lawyers to come. It is a privilege we have given. They have no right to come here. Secondly, where in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights does it say that a foreign lawyer who is granted the rare and unique privilege to appear in a foreign court can then abuse the privilege?

    Sir, he seems to think that Mr Lester has done nothing wrong. He should read the Government press statement again. Mr Lester, according to the account of the FCO itself, was in the forefront of legal circles exerting and mounting pressure in the United Kingdom. Secondly, he should read the references in the press statement to what Mr Lester said, not only to Ambassador Marshall but also to Mr Tiwari, Senior State Counsel - that he would take the matter up with the British Bar Council, with the British Foreign Secretary, and even the British Prime Minister. These are all threats and intimidation. And he thought that the Government would succumb to these threats and intimidation. He was wrong.

Column: 217



     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, if anyone should try to pressurize the Government through any form of activity, that does not mean that he is going to intimidate the Government. If that is how it is interpreted, then I suppose all those who are lobbying for the MNCs in Congress in the United States, could be said to be intimidating the US government. Similarly, there are also pressure groups in Britain. It may be a privilege for foreign QCs to work in Singapore, I suppose. But this has been going on for a long, long time. QCs are supposed to be part of the whole judicial system, since the Privy Council is today supposed to be the highest court in Singapore.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Cheng San GRC): Mr Chairman, Sir, thank you for allowing me to participate in this debate.

    Sir, since we are discussing QCs, particularly QC Lester, I was rather surprised to see in the Straits Times this morning that the British government had protested to the Singapore Government on this case. If I may quote:

    'We regret this action by the Singapore Government. Mr Lester enjoys the highest professional and public standing in courts throughout the Commonwealth, the European Community and elsewhere.'

    Sir, I am rather surprised that the British government has decided to get involved in this matter. This is purely a matter between the Singapore Government and QC Anthony Lester. He was given a professional visit pass to come and defend the case in Singapore, and he transgressed the rules that went with the professional visit pass. And I think the Government had every right to withdraw. For the British government to get worked up on this matter, I find it very difficult to follow. We did not protest over the Tan Wah Piow issue. He entered the United Kingdom, I believe, without a passport. So why these double standards?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, in response to Mr Chandra Das, let me say that I am as surprised as he is that the British government should take that stand, because the action taken by the Singapore Government really has got nothing to do with the British government. It has got nothing to do with any policy of the British government or with any decision or any depart-

Column: 218

ment of the British government. In fact, it has got nothing to do with the British government whatsoever. That the British government may have a high esteem of him in his activities in United Kingdom and elsewhere is totally irrelevant for the case at hand, because the action that we have taken against him is in relationship to his conduct vis-a-vis a case which involves him in Singapore. And it is for that that we have taken action. In other words, the action against Mr Lester has to do with our policy, which is a liberal policy of admitting QCs. But if any one QC, whoever he may be, whatever his connections may be with the British establishment, however high and esteemed others may have of him, if we conclude that he has abused the privilege, then we will take action. And that is what we have done, Sir.

     The Chairman: Dr Lee, do you want to withdraw your amendment?

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh: Sir, in view of what he has said, I withdraw my amendment.

    Head E -

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head E of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, I wish to speak on the topic of the Court of Final Appeal. In the debates earlier in the year, it is clear that the role of the Privy Council in our Judicial system is under review. In the debate on the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore

Column: 219

(Amendment) Bill on 25 January 1989, the Minister for Law said:

    'I might add that it is not just the security cases that we are concerned with. In fact, the Government has been concerned for some time over how long we can continue this system of appeals to the Privy Council. Some Members may know that during the British Empire, some of the judges who sat on the Privy Council had experience serving in the colonies or in the Commonwealth. That way, some of the judges in the Privy Council had valuable local perspective when overseas cases came up to the Privy Council. This was important.'

    The Minister also went on to say:

    'I should therefore add that there are also other areas, particularly of administrative and public law, where our courts must also have the final say. This is because the political, social and economic circumstances of a country are crucial factors in interpreting and applying such law by the judges of that country. However, we shall decide on these matters after careful deliberation.'

    Sir, as I have mentioned in an earlier debate, many of the lawyers that I have spoken to are prepared to do away with appeals to the Privy Council, provided that a permanent Court of Appeal is set up in Singapore. There are others, of course, who prefer to retain the Privy Council as the final Court of Appeal.

    Sir, the issue before us today is whether we are prepared to accept the concept of having our own permanent Court of Appeal. First come acceptance of the concept, then the challenge to deal with the problems involved, and admittedly there are major hurdles to cross!

    Sir, whether a permanent Court of Appeal should be set up must be based on sound principle and legal philosophy. The Hon. Minister himself, a Professor of Law, has wisely set out the reasons why the Privy Council is no longer relevant in Singapore's present day context (as I have quoted earlier). Some expressed the view that there are only about 10 cases of appeals to the Privy Council each year. So why set up a permanent Court of Appeal? The judges will not have enough workload! Others argue that if we have a permanent Court of Appeal in Singapore, we will be encouraging more litigation or appeals because appeals to the Privy Council in the United Kingdom can be an expensive affair.

Column: 220



    Sir, I reiterate that a permanent Court of Appeal should be set up based on sound principle and legal philosophy and not based on the economic theory of supply and demand. The fact that not many cases went up to the Privy Council could be due to a number of factors.

    (1) Perhaps it is too expensive;

    (2) Perhaps litigants are satisfied with the competence and fairness of Singapore courts. This, I believe, and hope, is the major reason. This is a good indication of our court's image and high standards;

    (3) Perhaps we have good lawyers at the Bar who do not indiscriminately advise their clients to appeal frivolously. This indicates that we have a mature, competent and responsible legal profession, something that we can all be proud of. I disagree with the Straits Times' assessment that there is a "general paucity of talent at the Bar". [Straits Times, 11th March 1989]. However, as the famous legal maxim goes, justice must not only be done, but justice must been seen to be done. What we are talking about is the doing of justice in Singapore. It is the whole business of a fair system of justice in Singapore, and not how many people will go to the Court of Appeal. If we do not set for ourselves the high ideal of our own Appellate Court system, the probability of miscarriage of justice is that much higher. The question is not how many will appeal, but rather when litigants are dissatisfied, do they have a choice?

    Sir, one very relevant question in the consideration of the setting up of an Appeal Court is that there is an acute shortage of Judges. This argument cannot be faulted. However, the point the GPC would like to make is that the Government should accept the proposal in principle, and work towards the establishment of a permanent Court of Appeal. If we cannot achieve this in the immediate future, can we do it in the next three or even five years? This Government has proved itself capable of handling the most intricate of problems, the most important of which is the survival and prosperity today of an independent Singapore of 600 sq km.

Column: 221



    I am confident that we can overcome this problem, given the political will to do so. We succeeded in the almost insurmountable economic and political spheres fraught with problems. Is the legal problem so insurmountable? There are many solutions to a problem, and I am an optimist. I will definitely not dismiss this important issue by wishing it away on the grounds of "idea impractical because of shortage of Judges and legal talent". [Straits Times, 11th March 1989].

    Let us remind ourselves that in Malaysia, where the legal training of lawyers and Judges is not dissimilar to that of Singapore, there is a permanent Court of Appeal. I would urge the Government that in assessing the suitability of potential judges, we should not place undue weight on the annual income of the person. The highest earner or best paid lawyer in town need not be the most suitable candidate for a potential judge. Integrity, honour, experience, wisdom and a sense of commitment to the law of the land and the national cause are more important.

    In closing, Sir, I would like to add that the absence of a permanent Court of Appeal would stultify the development of our law, and the development of the process of judicial decision making. A permanent Court of Appeal and its considered legal reasoning will no doubt enhance the stature of our courts. In time to come, our Court of Appeal will I am sure join the ranks of other distinguished courts,and perhaps even the Privy Council. This is our challenge, excellence in law in Singapore.

     Mr Loh Meng See (Kampong Glam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to support my Chairman, GPC for Home Affairs and Law, with regard to this subject on the permanent Court of Final Appeal.

    Sir, I take it that the Government will be reviewing the position of the Privy Council for Singapore. In so doing, I think there is a great need to consider a viable substitute in its place. It is my view that a permanent Court of Appeal of Singapore will be such a viable substitute.

    I am happy to note that provisions have been made to increase the number of

Column: 222

Judges for the financial year 1989. Unfortunately, as it stands now, other than the recent elevation of a High Court Judge, the number for FY 88 stood at 9 against the estimated need for 14 Judges. But nevertheless, it has demonstrated the Government's desire to seriously consider providing for more High Court Judges.

    Sir, it is important that the consideration of the shortage of legal talent in Singapore should not be over repeated. There is such a thing as self-fulfilling prophecy. The more often that we pronounce that there is a lack of talent in the legal field, the tendencey is that we believe in it and we believe that to be the truth.

    I think it is important, as I have mentioned earlier, that the Government set up a Law Review Commission to thoroughly review the judicial system in Singapore. Is it possible for us to develop a system whereby we could delegate more of the functions to the District Courts and the Subordinate Courts so that as much exposure and opportunities for development could be given to our legal personnel at the lower levels so that there will be promotional opportunities for such people.
